Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on . Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is
required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (517) 243-9743.
Sincerely,

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
CCI Rule 400.4113 (i) Employee records
(i) Directly from the Michigan state police or the
equivalent state law enforcement agency, Canadian
province, or other country where the person
usually resides or has resided in the previous 5
y ears.
Two out of 19 newly hired staff did not have their central registry results available
for review.
Repeat Violation Established
Original approved 11/14/2023, CAP approved 11/14/2023

CCI Rule 400.4147 Dental care
(2) A dental examination within 12 months prior to
admission shall be documented or there shall
be an examination not later than 90 calendar
days following admission.
Two out of three youth did not have dental examinations within 90 calendar days
following admission as required by the rule.
CCI Rule 400.4155 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter
care institutions; initial treatment plan
(3) The initial treatment plan shall include all of the
following:
(a) An assessment of the resident’s and family’s
strengths and needs.
Three out of three youth files reviewed were missing information in service plans
on familial strengths and needs
CCI Rule 400.4155 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter
care institutions; initial treatment plan
(3) The initial treatment plan shall include all of the
following:
(b) Plans for parent and child visitation.
Three out of three youth files reviewed were missing information in service plans
regarding parenting time plans.
CCI Rule 400.4155 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter
care institutions; initial treatment plan
(3) The initial treatment plan shall include all of the
following:
(f) Staff techniques for achieving the resident’s
treatment goals, including a specific
behavior management plan. The plan shall be
designed to minimize seclusion and restraint
and include a continuum of responses to
problem behaviors.
Three out of three youth files reviewed were missing information in service plans
regarding staff techniques for achieving youth's treatment goals.

CCI Rule 400.4155 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter
care institutions; initial treatment plan
(3) The initial treatment plan shall include all of the
following:
(g) Projected length of stay and next placement.
Three out of three youth files reviewed were missing information in service plans
regarding the projected length of stay and next placement.
CCI Rule 400.4155 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter
care institutions; initial treatment plan
(5) The social service supervisor shall approve,
countersign, and date the initial treatment plan.
Three out of three youth files reviewed were missing proper signatures in service
plans.
CCI Rule 400.4166 Discharge plan
(1) When a resident is discharged from institutional
care, all of the following information shall be
documented in the case record within 14 days
after discharge:
(a) The date of and reason for discharge, and
the new location of the child.
One out of two youth files reviewed were missing completed and timely discharge
plans.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• It was advised that the facility re-design all treatment plans, not just the initial in
order to ensure that Licensing requirements are being met for each.
• It was advised that alterations to intake forms could occur in order to better
guarantee all information that is needed to meet rule 4152 occurs, regardless
of the referral source or the likelihood that this information is easily available.

V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Consultation was not requested or required.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There was one substantiated incident of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period. This occurred during a physical altercation between staff and youth. This
investigation resulted in a confirmed case for one former staff member. As a result
of the investigation the staff member's employment was terminated.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 3 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The first
was a result of non-compliance at the time of original licensure. These findings
were all related to hiring practices and documentation. There is one repeat finding
during this inspection related to rule 400.4113 (i). The other two corrective action
plans came as a result of special investigations. SIR #2024C0001026SI produced
a CAP that contained action steps of the termination of employees and re-training
on behavioral management practices. SIR #2024C0001087SI produced a CAP
that contained action steps of following agency policy regarding the storage of
medications. There are no current concerns on CAP follow up or repeated
findings from those two corrective action plans.
Financial Overview
Yearly budgeting and financial overviews were provided, and no concerns were
noted.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
N/A
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator yearly assessment was completed on 04/09/2024. In this
documentation, the Chief Administrator assessed two Corrective Action Plans that
were the results of Special Investigations and their current effectiveness. The
agency has implemented biweekly, on the job training and reports this has had a
positive impact on staff. In addition, there was one unplanned discharge that was
analyzed. As a result, more staff will be utilized when completing any transport.

Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff were interviewed during an announced, face-to-face visit at the facility on
04/16/2024. All staff reported positive experiences working in the program, noting
that the structure had allowed them to build relationships with the youth. They felt
fulfilled and that the youth in the program could see benefit over time. All staff
stated that they felt supported by management.
Youth were interviewed during an announced, face-to-face visit at the facility on
04/16/2024. The youth reported positive experiences participating in the program.
They did note that it took some time to get used to the program's standards and
structure, but they stated they felt it could benefit them as they worked through it.
The youth stated they were working well in the education program despite not
having full time teachers present in person every day. They all stated their basic
needs were being met and they felt safe in the program.
Description of Agency Walk Through
Facility walk through was completed during an announced, face-to-face visit at the
facility on 04/16/2024. Both units being utilized were in clean and safe condition
and no safety concerns were noted anywhere in the building. It was discussed the
program could expand to additional units on the second floor of the building and
Technical Assistance was given to the Chief Administrator on how this could be
accomplished.

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
